title: SDE-based Multiplicative Noise Removal
abstract:
Multiplicative noise, also known as speckle or pepper noise, commonly affects
images produced by synthetic aperture radar (SAR), lasers, or optical lenses.
Unlike additive noise, which typically arises from thermal processes or
external factors, multiplicative noise is inherent to the system, originating
from the fluctuation in diffuse reflections. These fluctuations result in
multiple copies of the same signal with varying magnitudes being combined.
Consequently, despeckling, or removing multiplicative noise, necessitates
different techniques compared to those used for additive noise removal.
  In this paper, we propose a novel approach using Stochastic Differential
Equations based diffusion models to address multiplicative noise. We
demonstrate that multiplicative noise can be effectively modeled as a Geometric
Brownian Motion process in the logarithmic domain. Utilizing the Fokker-Planck
equation, we derive the corresponding reverse process for image denoising. To
validate our method, we conduct extensive experiments on two different
datasets, comparing our approach to both classical signal processing techniques
and contemporary CNN-based noise removal models. Our results indicate that the
proposed method significantly outperforms existing methods on perception-based
metrics such as FID and LPIPS, while maintaining competitive performance on
traditional metrics like PSNR and SSIM.
